Title: Uncovering Soccer Personas Using Clustering Algorithms¶

Introduction (What Is Clustering?)¶

In the realms of machine learning, a very common delineation is between:

  • supervised learning
  • unsupervised learning

The key difference is whether a target variable of interest is available. In other words, is there something for the training data to predict and compare with?

If not, it typically is an unsupervised learning problem, where we seek to unravel the "hidden" target variable using techniques that attempt to group similar data together.

During past data science work, I have led and implemented 2 technical projects related to clustering in different industries, which has deepened my appreciation for this problem space.¶

Usually, businesses would like to cluster commercial data for various purposes, such as discovering customer profiles to create mental models of their customers.

The commercial work I did revolved around clustering consumers to rank them for targeted marketing campaigns and customer support, and the applications are plenty.

However I wanted to switch it up and doing something fun while transferring my tacit knowledge, so I decided to work on soccer.

I'm an avid soccer player - one of my biggest sporting achievements was winning the under 10 7-a-side National Championships in Singapore where I scored the winning goal.

I never really reached that peak again even in my teens, but I've always grew strong domain expertise through futsal sessions and watching top European leagues - I supported Manchester United until Rooney left!

Hence, I wanted to take this opportunity to cluster a bunch of player data and build a soccer player recommender using clustering techniques.¶

What Is The Goal?¶

In the big leagues, teams are constantly in flux:

  • Players are bought and sold (2019 EPL transfer window value was £1.41bn)
  • Players get injured or ill (Average injuries per team in EPL 16/17 season was 57.5. The maximum team size is 25)
  • Player's mentality/ form/ physical performance changes over time

However, coaches aspire to have consistent performances as much as possible, pertaining to a specific style or end-result.

Top teams have a distinct style - Jurgen Klopp is known for his ‘Gegenpressing’. The EPL is known for being physical and direct, emanating the swashbuckling style of the English. How about the "Tiki-Taka" philosophy made famous by Pep Guardiola?

Coaches work with scouts to identify new players with similar profiles to their current squad.

This prepares them for ready substitutions - in case for sudden injuries, downtime or other reasons that leave a gaping hole in their formations, they still have someone to play a specific role in the team.

Hence, I will be building a tool for coaches and scouts that would recommend similar players outside their current squad to them, so they can acquire the right "replacements" for their desired roles, whoever the player is.

Statistics:
https://talksport.com/football/572055/every-premier-league-club-spent-summer-transfer-window-2019-2020/
https://www.physioroom.com/info/english-premier-league-injury-analysis-201617-season/

What Are We Working With?¶

We will be collecting soccer data from a variety of sources, including:

  • Kaggle 2018 FIFA & 2019 FIFA Player Ratings
  • Kaggle European Soccer Database (2007-2016)
  • Sofifa API Package

Get player hashtags from the api tool http://sofifa-api.herokuapp.com/api/v1/players/ (no need to timebox) SQL lite table data from the European Data dataset # https://www.kaggle.com/hugomathien/soccer 18/19 dataset from Kaggle

There are over 15k players in the top european leagues, with quantitative ratings (used in the video game) that serve as a proxy for their performances.

There are also more qualitative ratings such as hashtags and social media popularity from other data mining efforts out there.

In essence, majority of the data will come from sofifa, and the rest would come from social media.

Most of the analysis I've seen on player data online tends to be static, in other words restricted to a particular timestamp or year.

We can do better, since we know at any 1 time, players are in different periods of their career.¶

As player ratings have been recorded since 2007 to 2019, there is the opportunity to include some form of time-series analysis here, to factor changes in player performance, or changes in their positions or playing styles as they age.

During the pre-processing step, I will clean the data until all the feature variables of interest are all represented in 1 row.

1st Round of Data Cleaning (Removing Uneccessary Columns, Renaming Columns etc)¶

In [374]:
# removing columns not of direct interest
fifa_18 = fifa_18.drop(columns=['Unnamed: 0', 'Club Logo', 'Value', 'Wage', 'Club', 'Flag'])
fifa_19 = fifa_19.drop(columns=['Unnamed: 0', 'Club Logo', 'Value', 'Wage', 'Club', 'Flag',
                      'Release Clause', 'Jersey Number', 'Joined', 'Loaned From', 'Contract Valid Until', 'Real Face'])

# renaming some columns to fit with fifa_19
fifa_18.columns = ['Name', 'Age', 'Photo', 'Nationality', 'Overall', 'Potential',
       'Special', 'Acceleration', 'Aggression', 'Agility', 'Balance',
       'BallControl', 'Composure', 'Crossing', 'Curve', 'Dribbling',
       'Finishing', 'FKAccuracy', 'GKDiving', 'GKHandling',
       'GKKicking', 'GKPositioning', 'GKReflexes', 'HeadingAccuracy',
       'Interceptions', 'Jumping', 'LongPassing', 'LongShots', 'Marking',
       'Penalties', 'Positioning', 'Reactions', 'ShortPassing', 'ShotPower',
       'SlidingTackle', 'SprintSpeed', 'Stamina', 'StandingTackle',
       'Strength', 'Vision', 'Volleys', 'CAM', 'CB', 'CDM', 'CF', 'CM', 'ID',
       'LAM', 'LB', 'LCB', 'LCM', 'LDM', 'LF', 'LM', 'LS', 'LW', 'LWB',
       'Preferred Positions', 'RAM', 'RB', 'RCB', 'RCM', 'RDM', 'RF', 'RM',
       'RS', 'RW', 'RWB', 'ST']

# ordering columns to make more readable
columns_18 = ['ID','Name', 'Age', 'Photo', 'Nationality', 'Overall', 'Potential',
       'Special', 'CAM', 'CB', 'CDM', 'CF', 'CM', 
       'LAM', 'LB', 'LCB', 'LCM', 'LDM', 'LF', 'LM', 'LS', 'LW', 'LWB',
       'Preferred Positions', 'RAM', 'RB', 'RCB', 'RCM', 'RDM', 'RF', 'RM',
       'RS', 'RW', 'RWB', 'ST', 'Acceleration', 'Aggression', 'Agility', 'Balance',
       'BallControl', 'Composure', 'Crossing', 'Curve', 'Dribbling',
       'Finishing', 'FKAccuracy', 'HeadingAccuracy',
       'Interceptions', 'Jumping', 'LongPassing', 'LongShots', 'Marking',
       'Penalties', 'Positioning', 'Reactions', 'ShortPassing', 'ShotPower',
       'SlidingTackle', 'SprintSpeed', 'Stamina', 'StandingTackle',
       'Strength', 'Vision', 'Volleys', 'GKDiving', 'GKHandling',
       'GKKicking', 'GKPositioning', 'GKReflexes']
fifa_18 = fifa_18[columns_18]

fifa_18['Year'] = 2018
fifa_19['Year'] = 2019

       'Potential', 'PreferredFoot', 'Crossing', 'Finishing', 'HeadingAccuracy',
       'ShortPassing', 'Volleys', 'Dribbling', 'Curve', 'FKAccuracy',
       'long_passing', 'BallControl', 'Acceleration', 'SprintSpeed',

       'GKReflexes', 'Name', 'birthday', 'height', 'weight']

# ordering columns to make more readable

       'Potential', 'PreferredFoot', 'Crossing', 'Finishing', 'HeadingAccuracy',
       'ShortPassing', 'Volleys', 'Dribbling', 'Curve', 'FKAccuracy',

In [416]:
mapi_db = mapi_db.drop(columns=['work_rate', 'value', 'wage', 'release_clause', 'real_face'])

mapi_db.columns = ['age', 'birth_date', 'body_type', 'height', 'player_id',
       'International Reputation', 'Name', 'Overall', 'photo_url',
       'PlayerHashtags', 'PlayerTraits', 'positions', 'Potential',
       'preferred_foot', 'skill_moves',
       'skills', 'social', 'weak_foot', 'weight']

columns_mapi = ['player_id', 'Name', 'age', 'birth_date', 'body_type', 'height','weight',
       'International Reputation', 'Overall', 'photo_url',
       'PlayerHashtags', 'PlayerTraits', 'positions', 'Potential',
       'preferred_foot', 'skill_moves', 'skills', 'social', 'weak_foot']
mapi_db = mapi_db[columns_mapi]

# key columns for matching to an ID - focus on precision over recall
# mapi_db[['birth_date', 'height', 'Name']].head()

In [81]:
def convert_date(x):
    return datetime.datetime.strptime(x, '%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S')
    
euro_db['date'] = euro_db['date'].apply(convert_date)
